revision.text:
{{Infobox military unit|unit_name = 199th Motor Rifle Division|dates = 1970–1989|country = {{flag|Soviet Union}}|branch = [[Soviet Army]]|type = Motorized infantry|garrison = [[Krasny Kut, Primorsky Krai|Krasny Kut]]}}The '''199th Motor Rifle Division''' was a motorized infantry division of the [[Soviet Army]] from 1970 to 1989. The division was based in [[Krasny Kut, Primorskye Krai]] and became a storage base in 1989.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = 199th Motorised Rifle Division|url = http://www.ww2.dk/new/army/msd/199msd.htm|website = www.ww2.dk|access-date = 2016-01-13|last = Holm|first = Michael}}</ref>
== History == The division was formed in January 1970 in Krasny Kut, Primorskye Krai. It was subordinated to the [[5th Red Banner Army]]. During the Cold War, the division was maintained at 70% strength. On 1 October 1989, it became the 5506th Weapons and Equipment Storage Base.<ref name=":0" /><ref>Feskov et al 2013, p. 589</ref>
== Composition == In 1988, the division included the following units. All units were based at Krasny Kut unless noted.<ref name=":0" /> * 526th Motorized Rifle Regiment * 594th Motorized Rifle Regiment * 610th Motorized Rifle Regiment ([[Spassk-Dalny]]) * 71st Tank Regiment * 2183rd Artillery Regiment (Spassk-Dalnyy) * 426th Anti-Aircraft Missile Regiment * Separate Missile Battalion * Separate Anti-Tank Artillery Battalion * Separate Reconnaissance Battalion * Separate Engineer-Sapper Battalion * 1059th Separate Communications Battalion * Separate Chemical Defence Company * Separate Equipment Maintenance and Recovery Battalion * 365th Separate Medical Battalion * Separate Material Supply Battalion
== References == <references /> *{{Cite book|title=Вооруженные силы СССР после Второй Мировой войны: от Красной Армии к Советской|last=Feskov|first=V.I.|last2=Golikov|first2=V.I.|last3=Kalashnikov|first3=K.A.|last4=Slugin|first4=S.A.|publisher=Scientific and Technical Literature Publishing|year=2013|isbn=9785895035306|location=Tomsk|language=Russian|trans-title=The Armed Forces of the USSR after World War II: From the Red Army to the Soviet: Part 1 Land Forces}}
